comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A train wreck is hardly a help in finding a date. Zapata was in the habit of wrecking trains, it appears. See, for example, The day book. (Chicago, Ill.) 1911-1917, February 10, 1913, Image 27 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1913-02-10/ed-... or NYT of April 09, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20815FC3F5D17738... in column 3 of page 2 of a feature on Zapata.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Some one knows where and when this photo was taken?

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Is it possible that this is the train mentioned in The Salt Lake Tribune, issue WEDNESDAY MORNING, FEBRUARY 26, 1913? The Library of Congress, Chronicling America ZAPATISTAS ARE HOSTILE; BURN A MILITARY TRAIN. ...The Zapatistas, however, have definitely proclaimed their hostility to the Huerta regime and to make their position clear yesterday attacked and burned a goverment military train. ...In the south the Zapatistas continue burning and raiding and an attack on a military train between Ozumba and Mexico City leaves llttle room for doubt as to their attitude toward the new administration. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045396/1913-02-26/ed-... Although call nrs do not stablish a date, 3034s are frecuently seen in pictures about the ten tragic days in February 1913. Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Dr. Duarte, thank you for your research. But unless we can find a newpaper article with a photo to match or closely resemble this one, we may not have a specific date.
